job_Description: What Success Looks Like In This Job                   The Epidemiology and Data Science Division Director is an exciting, new position in Adams County, working closely with the Public Health Project Director, internal departments, and external stakeholders to support needs and requests around public health data. This position will articulate a clear, compelling vision for public health informatics, epidemiology, and health-related geospatial work, will support department-wide strategic initiatives and provide direct support and technical assistance and guidance around public health data needs and innovative techniques for public health data analysis. The individual in this role will lead and manage a team of epidemiologists, data scientists, and other analysts responsible for establishing, conducting, and advancing public health informatics and epidemiology at Adams County. Specific tasks may include data collection, data management, data analysis, and data reporting. Works collaboratively with Adams County Information, Technology, and Innovation (ITi) to align IT infrastructure with public health information management needs. Advocates for data-driven decision-making at all levels of the agency. Works collaboratively with other County staff to coordinate, integrate, and align efforts to maximize capabilities and efficiencies. Works collaboratively with other local public health agencies, the state health department, and health care systems partners on regional data collection and sharing efforts.       The selected candidate will be responsible for overseeing the transfer of public health informatics work to Adams County and will play a lead role in developing, implementing, monitoring, and continuously improving Adams County public health informatics program. This individual will oversee the creation and hiring of positions responsible for managing projects, gathering business requirements, identifying relevant data sources, selecting software and analytic systems, conducting data/statistical analyses, creating visualizations and reports. This position will report directly to the Public Health Project Director and will assist with the transition of public health data services from Tri-County Health Department to a county-specific structure based on the five Social Determinants of Health and the unique needs of the Adams County community and will be aligned to the vision of becoming the most inclusive and innovative County in the United States.       Applies epidemiology and statistical methods to understand the distribution and determinants of disease in populations in order to generate knowledge used to guide decision-making and prioritization surrounding Adams County’s efforts to improve population health. This includes managing processes and procedures to provide current research, data management, and statistical analyses for evidence-based decision-making, using data for program planning and evaluation, grant applications, and policy development. Develops methods of collecting, analyzing, and disseminating data and requires understanding of program processes and methods of prevention, intervention, and control of diseases of public health importance.       Epidemiology supervision:  Oversees masters and doctorate epidemiologists for surveillance and investigations of diseases, injuries and other health issues. Works closely with public health data analytic staff, health informaticians, and diverse community partners. Manages teams of both population health epidemiologists and communicable disease epidemiologists.       Health and community data collection:  This role will create usable information from data that supports a holistic understanding of health, centered in health equity, which can be communicated to Adams County staff, partners, community members, and municipal agencies through a variety of communications channels, as needed, to support programmatic efforts and goals. This requires an understanding of cross-sector data and concepts related to (but not limited to) public health, urban planning, criminal justice, education, municipal level policies, environmental hazards, and emergency preparedness. In addition to health data, this position requires the ability to understand, query, and manage non-traditional data sources including American Community Survey, State Demographer population data, crime, land-use, and other data sources as needed.       GIS Administration and Services:  Public-health focused GIS services are provided by this position. This includes the administration of GIS licensing through the GIS software vendor, maintenance of both the internal GIS server, web-based cloud server, web-based GIS applications and websites, and the storage and maintenance of geospatial data. In addition to administering GIS infrastructure, this position oversees all GIS data and mapping requests as needed by staff, including print maps, interactive web-based maps, creating geospatial data, and the deployment of publicly available data through public-facing websites.       Data management:  responsibilities for this position include the development, maintenance, and enforcement of standards related to data storage, file naming and organization, and project documentation and organization. Data are stored on multiple internal servers and databases and in external cloud-based systems. Understanding how these data and used and the implications for storage across these systems is critical in effective deployment and utilization of data within the program as well as to our customers. This is position is responsible for continual assessment of these processes to facilitate an organized backend that maximizes project collaboration and access to all health data analysts. Data/analysis communication materials: include innovative and non-traditional ways to develop and deploy of information from relevant data and analyses supporting TCHD programmatic work. This includes the presentations, handouts, factsheets, reports, websites, interactive web-based GIS maps, dashboards, and infographics.
